G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000 when considering Plaintiff’s past and future medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and pain and suffering and other non‑economic damages.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2 and 9.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and 9 because the cause of action arose in Suffolk County and Defendant was operating a motor vehicle at 55 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Suffolk County, Massachusetts, at the time of the incident.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Plaintiff was operating his bicycle in a careful, prudent, and lawful manner, complying with applicable traffic signs, signals, and markings, and in accordance with Massachusetts bicycle and traffic laws, including but not limited to G.L. c. 85, § 11B, G.L. c. 89, and G.L. c. 90.

G.L. c. 89.proposition: Plaintiff was operating his bicycle in a careful, prudent, and lawful manner, complying with applicable traffic signs, signals, and markings, and in accordance with Massachusetts bicycle and traffic laws, including but not limited to G.L. c. 85, § 11B, G.L. c. 89, and G.L. c. 90.

G.L. c. 90.proposition: Plaintiff was operating his bicycle in a careful, prudent, and lawful manner, complying with applicable traffic signs, signals, and markings, and in accordance with Massachusetts bicycle and traffic laws, including but not limited to G.L. c. 85, § 11B, G.L. c. 89, and G.L. c. 90.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 90, § 14 provides that motorists shall “slow down and pass bicycles only when it is safe to do so” and requires due care to avoid colliding with bicyclists; it further provides that motor vehicle operators and passengers shall “not open a door unless it is reasonably safe to do so without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists,” and shall not leave a door open on the side available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B and related provi.proposition: G.L. c. 85, § 11B and related provisions recognize bicyclists as lawful and legitimate users of public ways and require that they be afforded the same rights and subject to the same duties as drivers of motor vehicles, except as otherwise specifically provided.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, comparative negligence, any negligence on the part of Plaintiff—if found to exist and to be less than 51% of the total negligence—would merely reduce, but not bar, his recovery; Plaintiff denies any comparative fault but pleads in the alternative that his negligence, if any, was less than that of Defendant.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff his taxable costs of suit incurred herein pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all motorists owe a duty of reasonable care to other users of the roadway, including bicyclists lawfully traveling in bike lanes and on public ways.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard concerns premises liability and the treatment of categories like licensees, invitees, and trespassers. It does not address duties owed by motorists, roadway users, or bicyclists, nor does it discuss traffic or roadway negligence standards. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts motorists owe a duty of reasonable care to bicyclists using bike lanes or public ways.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all motorists owe a duty of reasonable care to other users of the roadway, including bicyclists lawfully traveling in bike lanes and on public ways.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns social host and landowner negligence liability for injuries caused by fireworks on residential property. It does not discuss motorists, roadway duties, bicyclists, or bike lanes, nor does it articulate any general rule about duties owed by drivers to other users of public ways. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition regarding motorists’ duty of reasonable care to bicyclists on public roadways.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.relevant_excerpt: The duty of a landowner under general principles of common-law negligence governing dangerous conditions on his land is established. “A landowner must act as a reasonable [person] in maintaining . . . property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: The elements of a negligence claim in Massachusetts are: (1) the existence of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) a causal connection between the breach and the plaintiff’s injury; and (4) actual damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the elements of a negligence claim in Massachusetts in its general discussion of negligence. It lists duty, breach, damage, and causal relation between breach and damage, which aligns with the proposition’s formulation of duty, breach, causation, and actual damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: The elements of a negligence claim in Massachusetts are: (1) the existence of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) a causal connection between the breach and the plaintiff’s injury; and (4) actual damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes what the plaintiffs must prove to prevail on their negligence claims, listing breach of duty, actual loss (damages), and causation as essential elements, and it relies on Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 and a Massachusetts tort treatise. Although the passage does not separately enumerate "duty" because it analyzes breach of duty, it clearly presupposes the existence of a duty and identifies breach, causation, and damages as required elements, thus supporting the standard four-element formulation of negligence in Massachusetts.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: A violation of a safety statute designed to protect a particular class of persons, such as bicyclists and other lawful road users, may be evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the effect of violating a safety statute (here, G.L. c. 138, § 69) on civil negligence liability. It reiterates Massachusetts law that such a statutory violation does not constitute negligence per se but is only "some evidence" of negligence with respect to the harms the statute was designed to prevent. That directly supports the proposition that violation of a safety statute aimed at protecting a class of persons may be evidence of negligence, but not conclusive proof.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only "some evidence" of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 83 (19.proposition: A violation of a safety statute designed to protect a particular class of persons, such as bicyclists and other lawful road users, may be evidence of negligence.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 83 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence, but it frames the rule in terms of "any action by a person whose only relationship to the premises ... is that of a lawful visitor" and in the context of tenement-house safety statutes. It does not discuss statutes specifically designed to protect bicyclists or other classes of road users, nor does it generalize to safety statutes aimed at particular classes of persons in the way the proposition states. The proposition extrapolates the case’s reasoning to a different statutory context (road users/bicyclists) that the court never addresses.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 83 (19.relevant_excerpt: We hold today that the landlord’s duty of reasonable care to all visitors lawfully on premises within his control extends to his tenants’ visitors. Therefore, violation of a safety statute constitutes evidence of negligence in any action by a person whose only relationship to the premises where the injury occurred is that of a lawful visitor. In so far as Stapleton, supra, is inconsistent with this decision, it is hereby overruled.

Koonce v. Aldo Realty Trust, 8 Mass. App.raw_text: Koonce v. Aldo Realty Trust, 8 Mass. App. Ct. 1001 (1979) (Rule 1:28 decision, noting duty to avoid creating sudden obstruction in path of plaintiff)
Koonce v. Aldo Realty Trust, 8 Mass. App.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long recognized that an operator of a motor vehicle has a duty to exercise reasonable care in opening doors of a parked vehicle so as not to endanger passing traffic.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 60–61 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long recognized that an operator of a motor vehicle has a duty to exercise reasonable care in opening doors of a parked vehicle so as not to endanger passing traffic.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: Nothing in this opinion—indeed, in this excerpt or the underlying case generally—concerns motor vehicles, parked cars, or duties in opening vehicle doors. Mullins v. Pine Manor College addresses premises liability and foreseeability of criminal acts on a college campus, not roadway duties of vehicle operators. It therefore does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about a motorist’s duty when opening a car door.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The provided text and the Mullins v. Pine Manor College decision as a whole discuss campus security, locking systems, foreseeability of criminal assaults, and proximate cause in a premises liability context, and do not address motor vehicles or duties related to opening doors of parked vehicles.

Zeigler v. Rater, 318 Mass. 76, 79 (1945.proposition: Negligence may be established by circumstantial evidence and reasonable inferences, and a plaintiff is not required to exclude every possible cause other than the defendant’s negligence.
Zeigler v. Rater, 318 Mass. 76, 79 (1945.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory trespass for wrongful cutting of trees and the meaning of “wilfully” and “without license” under G.L. c. 242, § 7. It does not discuss negligence, circumstantial evidence, or the burden of excluding alternative causes. Therefore it does not support the proposition about proving negligence by circumstantial evidence and reasonable inferences.
Zeigler v. Rater, 318 Mass. 76, 79 (1945.relevant_excerpt: The statute (G. L. [Ter. Ed.] c. 242, § 7) on which this count is based provides that “A person who without license wilfully cuts down, carries away ... or otherwise destroys trees ... on the land of another shall be liable to the owner in tort for three times the amount of the damages assessed therefor; but if it is found that the defendant had good reason to believe that the land on which the trespass was committed was his own or that he was otherwise lawfully authorized to do the acts complained of, he shall be liable for single damages only.” The statute requires that the cutting be done “without license” and “wilfully.”

Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.raw_text: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 453 (1969)
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.proposition: Negligence may be established by circumstantial evidence and reasonable inferences, and a plaintiff is not required to exclude every possible cause other than the defendant’s negligence.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.case_name: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses foreseeability and duty in the context of a bar’s responsibility to protect patrons from an intoxicated assailant, but it does not address the evidentiary standard for proving negligence by circumstantial evidence or the need (or lack thereof) to exclude other possible causes. The court focuses on what the jury could infer about foreseeability and statutory violations, not on any rule that a plaintiff need not exclude every possible non-negligent cause. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: "The testimony warranted the jury’s verdict. ... It was open to the jury to find that the defendant’s employees had general knowledge of Martel’s previous experience as a patron and should have realized on the occasion here considered the need for repressing him. The jury could have found that the defendant’s agents should have tried to stop his drunken staggerings the length of the aisle, and if they did not attempt completely to remove him from the scene, at least should have provided some safeguard for the defendant’s patrons."

Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 255 (1.proposition: A tortfeasor in Massachusetts “takes the plaintiff as he finds him,” and is responsible for all damages proximately caused by his negligence, even if the plaintiff is particularly susceptible to injury.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 255 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts the rule that a negligent actor remains liable where his injury makes the plaintiff “peculiarly susceptible” to disease and is then responsible for the resulting harm. This is a classic articulation of the “egg-shell plaintiff” / “take the plaintiff as you find him” doctrine: the defendant is liable for all consequences where his negligence lowers the victim’s vitality and thereby leads to greater or different injury than would occur in a healthier person. Thus it directly supports the proposition that a Massachusetts tortfeasor must answer for all damages proximately caused, even where special susceptibility is involved.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 255 (1.relevant_excerpt: “It is settled that, where an injury arising from a cause which entails liability on the defendant combines with a preexisting or a subsequently acquired disease to bring about greater harm to the plaintiff than would have resulted from the injury alone, the defendant may be liable for all the consequences. … The result follows that, if any injury progressively so reduces the general vitality of the person injured as to make him peculiarly susceptible to a disease which is contracted, the chain of causation is not thereby broken as matter of law.”

O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.raw_text: O’Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Mass. 586, 590 (1988)
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.proposition: A tortfeasor in Massachusetts “takes the plaintiff as he finds him,” and is responsible for all damages proximately caused by his negligence, even if the plaintiff is particularly susceptible to injury.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.support_reasoning: The opinion in O’Connor v. Raymark focuses on exposure and causation standards in multi-tortfeasor asbestos litigation, particularly the meaning of “substantial contributing cause” and joint and several liability where damages are inseparable. It does not discuss the “eggshell skull” or “take your plaintiff as you find him” rule, nor does it address special susceptibility to injury. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a tortfeasor is liable for all damages even if the plaintiff is unusually vulnerable.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.relevant_excerpt: “We have said before, and we repeat, ‘that if two or more wrongdoers negligently contribute to the personal injury of another by their several acts, which operate concurrently, so that in effect the damages suffered are rendered inseparable, they are jointly and severally liable.’ Chase v. Roy, 363 Mass. 402, 408 (1973). Burke v. Hodge, 217 Mass. 182, 184-185 (1914). … Furthermore, as the plaintiff argues, a defendant’s position is no better if the concurring acts of others were not negligent acts.”

Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass\u.raw_text: Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass’n–Abundant Life Communities, Inc., 458 Mass. 580, 589 (2011)
Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass\u.proposition: Pain and suffering and other non‑economic damages are recoverable in negligence actions under Massachusetts common law.
Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass\u.case_name: Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass'n - Abundant Life Communities, Inc.
Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether private nuisance claims fall within the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act and whether sovereign immunity is waived; it does not address the types of damages recoverable in negligence actions, nor does it discuss pain and suffering or non‑economic damages at all. The cited page focuses on defining private nuisance and situating it within the Act, not on what categories of damages are recoverable under Massachusetts common‑law negligence. Therefore, this case does not support the proposition about recoverability of pain and suffering and other non‑economic damages in negligence actions.
Morrissey v. New England Deaconess Ass\u.relevant_excerpt: “As relevant herein, G. L. c. 258, § 2, provides, in pertinent part: ‘Public employers shall be liable for injury or loss of property … caused by the negligent or wrongful act or omission of any public employee while acting within the scope of his office or employment, in the same manner and to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances….’ … In Count III of his amended complaint, Morrissey asserted a claim against the Commonwealth for private nuisance, alleging interference with the use and enjoyment of the Trust property.”

Furtado v. Furtado, 380 Mass. 137, 142 (.proposition: Pain and suffering and other non‑economic damages are recoverable in negligence actions under Massachusetts common law.
Furtado v. Furtado, 380 Mass. 137, 142 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal contempt case arising from failure to comply with a support order and is focused on the distinction between civil and criminal contempt and the procedural protections required in criminal contempt proceedings. It does not involve a negligence action, does not discuss tort damages, and nowhere addresses the availability or measure of pain and suffering or other non‑economic damages under Massachusetts common law. It therefore cannot be authority for the recoverability of pain and suffering in negligence cases.
Furtado v. Furtado, 380 Mass. 137, 142 (.relevant_excerpt: There is a reasonably clear distinction between a civil contempt proceeding and a criminal contempt proceeding in terms of the purpose of the judgment. Civil contempt proceedings are “remedial and coercive,” intended to achieve compliance with the court’s orders for the benefit of the complainant. … On the other hand, a criminal contempt proceeding is “exclusively punitive. It is designed wholly to punish an attempt to prevent the course of justice.”
